Justification: The gradual onset of jaundice, dark urine, pale stools, and mild abdominal discomfort are consistent with viral hepatitis. Although there is no recent travel history, Hepatitis A can still be contracted through contaminated food or water.
The presence of jaundice and lethargy in a child could suggest hemolytic anemia, where increased breakdown of red blood cells leads to elevated bilirubin levels.
In young children, biliary atresia can present with jaundice, pale stools, and dark urine due to obstruction of bile flow.
A mild, hereditary condition that can cause jaundice due to increased levels of unconjugated bilirubin, often triggered by stress or fasting.
Although less common in young children, autoimmune hepatitis can present with jaundice and lethargy, and should be considered if other causes are ruled out.
This congenital condition can cause jaundice, abdominal pain, and pale stools due to bile duct obstruction.
While the patient is not on any medications, it is important to consider any possible over-the-counter medications or supplements that might have been overlooked.
